entry.title: Resources and Further Reading
entry.summary: Below are all of the informational pages and news articles used to research this project. All of these resources present great further reading and are sure to provide even more information than I was able to present in this project. In addition, for a research…
entry.content:
Below are all of the informational pages and news articles used to research this project. All of these resources present great further reading and are sure to provide even more information than I was able to present in this project.

In addition, for a research study on the need to diversify the National Park System, here is a link to a study conducted by researchers at Colorado State University and published by the National Park Service.

Finally, I want to highlight the National Park Foundation. The NPF is a foundation serving a number of functions, with the goal of improving education and "creating equal and abundant opportunities for all audiences" to experience our National Parks.

Resources

Djossa, Christina. “How U.S. National Parks Are Making Themselves More Accessible and Inclusive.” National Geographic, National Geographic, 22 Oct. 2021, https://www.nationalgeographic.com/travel/article/diversity-accessibility-representation-inclusion.  

Freedman, Andrew. “Biden Picks Native American Conservationist to Run the National Park Service.” Axios, 18 Aug. 2021, https://www.axios.com/biden-charles-sams-park-service-native-american-cf496a95-d4aa-4ea1-90ba-4164ec1aaa39.html.  

“Native Americans.” National Parks Service, U.S. Department of the Interior, https://www.nps.gov/jotr/learn/historyculture/indians.htm.  

“Our History - the Paiute Indian Tribe of Utah.” Utah Paiutes, 18 Oct. 2021, https://www.utahpaiutes.org/our-history/.  

“People - Joshua Tree.” National Parks Service, U.S. Department of the Interior, https://www.nps.gov/jotr/learn/historyculture/people.htm.  

Repanshek, Kurt. “National Park Service Issues 5-Year ‘Call to Action’ Plan for Moving toward Its Second Century.” National Parks Traveler, 2011, https://www.nationalparkstraveler.org/2011/08/national-park-service-issues-5-year-call-action-plan-moving-toward-its-second-century8687.  

Rott, Nathan. “Don't Care about National Parks? The Park Service Needs You To.” NPR, NPR, 9 Mar. 2016, https://www.npr.org/2016/03/09/463851006/dont-care-about-national-parks-the-park-service-needs-you-to.  

“Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation: Yosemite Mariposa's First People.” Discover Yosemite National Park, 12 Nov. 2021, https://www.yosemite.com/yosemite-mariposas-first-people/.  

“Yosemite Indians.” National Parks Service, U.S. Department of the Interior, https://www.nps.gov/yose/learn/historyculture/yosemite-indians.htm.  

“Yosemite Indians: Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation: United States.” SouthernSierra Miwuk, https://www.southernsierramiwuknation.org/.  

“Zion National Park History: A Brief History of Zion National Park.” ZionNationalPark.com, 2 July 2021, https://zionnationalpark.com/zion-national-park/zion-national-park-history/.

entry.title: Present Day
entry.summary: "We know that visitation does not reflect the diversity of the nation, and that’s a concern" - Jon Jarvis, Former Director of the National Park Service One of the greatest advantages of the National Park System is its large geographic footprint and lack of…
entry.content:
"We know that visitation does not reflect the diversity of the nation, and that’s a concern" - Jon Jarvis, Former Director of the National Park Service

One of the greatest advantages of the National Park System is its large geographic footprint and lack of exclusionary policies, which give it the potential to host an incredibly diverse range of visitors. In its ideal state, the National Park System provides a sanctuary and opportunity to appreciate nature for citizens and international visitors of all races and ethnicities. Unfortunately, in its history, the National Park System has largely failed to do that. In official and unofficial surveys, it has consistently been found that National Parks visitors are overwhelmingly and disproportionately white. This is likely due to a number of factors, including wealth disparity, transportation access, and geographic disparities in demographics. 


The National Park Service has made it a priority to address this concern in their policies and practices. In 2011, then-director of the NPS Jon Jarvis introduced his “Call to Action” plan, aimed to narrow the gap between population demographics and actual visitation numbers. While these numbers still remain skewed, the NPS has shown a clear and concentrated effort to improve their relationship with minority communities. In particular, the department is working to change their internal culture, expand outreach and education, and improve affordability. Read more about these efforts in a great article from National Geographic here (free sign-up required). 


On top of these efforts, an important step was taken recently to honor the history of the National Parks and those that originally inhabited them. When Charles Sams was confirmed as President Biden’s appointee as director of the National Park Service, he became the first Director of Native American descent in the history of the department. This was a celebrated step for the administration, and Director Sams has spearheaded efforts to preserve and share the rich cultural histories of our parks. 


Without a doubt, there is still much work to be done for our National Park System to represent our nation’s diversity and honor the history of the lands we now preserve, but the actions of the National Park Service over the past two decades have inspired hope that this is an attainable goal in future generations. As a largely apolitical department in the federal government, the NPS has the freedom to operate with its own goals in mind and continue to improve upon one of our nation’s greatest achievements.

entry.title: The History of Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary: The topography and harsh desert climate of the Joshua Tree region gives it a distinctive history of human interaction. The intense swings between heat and cold in days and nights made early living in this area very difficult, and the lack of natural cover in…
entry.content:
The topography and harsh desert climate of the Joshua Tree region gives it a distinctive history of human interaction. The intense swings between heat and cold in days and nights made early living in this area very difficult, and the lack of natural cover in the terrain meant that there were few viable locations for groups to settle in. Still, small groups of Native Americans made the most of the area. The Pinto tribes were the first to inhabit the Joshua Tree area, over 5,000 years ago. Civilizations in this area remained small and volatile, as it was difficult to maintain significant population numbers in such a harsh climate. One location, the Oasis of Mara, stands out as a primary representation of this trend. Originally inhabited by the Serrano people, it was also home to communities such as the Chemehuevi and the Cahuilla. The Oasis of Mara provided a water source and some cover for small communities to exist, and this is one of only a few well-documented long-term establishments. 


By the early part of the 20th century, most native populations had vanished from the Joshua Tree area. This was largely due to a massive influx of land developers and cactus poachers paving roads through the area. Where these populations migrated to is a mystery, but they likely moved further into the desert to escape the threat of forced relocation. In 1936, Joshua Tree was set aside as a national monument, halting all development inside the laid out borders and protecting the natural land. It was not until 1994 that Joshua Tree was designated as a National Park. 


Today, Joshua Tree preserves and protects the former native lands, but much of the history of this area has been erased by time. Unlike in many other parks, Native Americans did not leave much evidence of civilizations behind, outside of some tools, pots, and rock art. These remnants are now protected by the park, but the park is largely focused on preserving the natural land and the unique species that reside there.

entry.title: The History of Yosemite National Park
entry.summary: For over 5,500 years, the people of the Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation have called Yosemite Valley home. While harsh weather and natural environments are not uncommon in Yosemite Valley, the area served as a sanctuary for these tribes, and they were closely tied to their…
entry.content:
For over 5,500 years, the people of the Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation have called Yosemite Valley home. While harsh weather and natural environments are not uncommon in Yosemite Valley, the area served as a sanctuary for these tribes, and they were closely tied to their lands. The rugged terrain and sheltered settlements served to protect the Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation from incursions by Spanish, American, and Mexican colonists, and for centuries they were able to live peacefully under the beautiful landscape that they honored. However, the California Gold Rush in 1849 changed all of that. Outside settlers finally reached Yosemite Valley, and they wasted no time in conquering and relocating the local tribes. Within a few years, the Southern Sierra Miwuk people, as well as all the other small local tribes, were all but pushed out of their ancestral lands. Today, small pockets of Southern Sierra Miwuk people still remain in Mariposa County, where they work closely with the park to ensure that their lands are still honored and their history is still taught to visitors. 


Many names and traditions in Yosemite National Park are drawn from Southern Sierra Miwok culture, including the Yosemite name itself. Several prominent locations in the park also have traditional names, and the park also presents many aspects of Southern Sierra Miwok culture, through presentations, museums, and preserved sites. Despite the best efforts of Yosemite National Park’s organizers, the Southern Sierra Miwuk Nation is still petitioning the US government for federal recognition as a protected tribe, a fight that has endured since 1982. You can learn more about the nation and their fight for recognition on their website.

entry.title: The History of Zion National Park
entry.summary: Long before Mormon settlers and missionaries reached Southern Utah and the Zion Canyon, the area was inhabited by the Paiute tribe of Native Americans. While these groups worked together to explore the area further and set up functioning communities, contact with White settlers also brought…
entry.content:
Long before Mormon settlers and missionaries reached Southern Utah and the Zion Canyon, the area was inhabited by the Paiute tribe of Native Americans. While these groups worked together to explore the area further and set up functioning communities, contact with White settlers also brought difficulty to the lives of the Paiutes. Naturally, disease and violence wreaked havoc on the local population, and within a few decades, the Paiute population had plummeted. The modern day Paiute tribe says this decline took them from thousands of members in the tribe to under 800. 

As the Zion area and the surrounding cities were developed over the coming years, the region was swarmed by an influx of visitors, ranging from permanent settlers to adventure-seeking explorers. Mormon settlers continued to protect the area, recognizing the unique beauty that the canyon held. One well-known explorer, John Wesley Powell, gave the region an alternate name, calling it Mukuntuweap, a Paiute word that means “straight canyon”. In 1909, President William Taft declared the area to be federally protected under this Paiute name, and Mukuntuweap National Monument was born. However, in 1918, the assistant director of the National Parks Service, Horace Albright, took it upon himself to change the name to Zion National Monument, and a year later, it was designated as a national park under the same name. 

The history of the Paiute people is often overlooked and erased, with park's the sudden name change serving as the perfect evidence of this trend. Today, the Paiute tribes are still recovering from the near extinction of their people. The Paiutes are now a nation of five tribes in Southern Utah, and they continue to fight for a place to live in their native land, not the reservation they were assigned to in the 1950s. For more information on the Paiute tribes, visit their website here.

entry.title: Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary: Hidden out in the desert near Palm Springs, Joshua Tree is an experience unlike many others. Defined by its rocky structures and namesake trees, this park presents the unusual geography of a desert that sits at high elevation. With very few mapped hikes and landmarks,…
entry.content:
Hidden out in the desert near Palm Springs, Joshua Tree is an experience unlike many others. Defined by its rocky structures and namesake trees, this park presents the unusual geography of a desert that sits at high elevation. With very few mapped hikes and landmarks, this park is perfect for those who prefer exploring on their own. More confident visitors can climb up huge rock formations, eager explorers can set out to forger thei own path, or young families can observe the unique wildlife all around. This park completely changes in the darkness when the desert comes to life, making it a popular camping destination. While less is known about early activity in this park, it is still clear that it is a land that holds a significant history.

Here is a video highlighting how unique Joshua Tree is, along with some history of the people there (though importantly not the native inhabitants):

entry.title: Yosemite National Park
entry.summary: Set back in central California far to the east of San Francisco, Yosemite National Park is a favorite destination for adventurers of all kinds. With massive granite peaks and tree-filled valleys, this park offers fun of all varieties. Daring rock clibers can grapple up the…
entry.content:
Set back in central California far to the east of San Francisco, Yosemite National Park is a favorite destination for adventurers of all kinds. With massive granite peaks and tree-filled valleys, this park offers fun of all varieties. Daring rock clibers can grapple up the side of the famous El Capitan, while families relax and picnic in the valley below. Flowing waterfalls serve to accent the majesty of this park, especially in the winter and spring. With a rich history and a present day reputation as a must-see park, Yosemite is one of the most well-known destinations in the National Park System.

Here are some highlights:

entry.title: About the Author
entry.summary: Ryan Orlando is a fourth year political science student at UCLA, with a concentration in American politics and minors in digital humanities and public affairs. He is a national park annual passholder and thouroghly enjoys exploring any park he can get to. Through this site,…
entry.content: Ryan Orlando is a fourth year political science student at UCLA, with a concentration in American politics and minors in digital humanities and public affairs. He is a national park annual passholder and thouroghly enjoys exploring any park he can get to. Through this site, he hopes to educate on the history and importance of our national parks system, as well as raise awareness of the original owners of those lands. In his free time, Ryan enjoys watching and playing sports, and hanging out with his family, friends, and dog, Kona.

entry.title: Zion National Park
entry.summary: Located in Southern Utah, about 3 hours from Las Vegas, the majestic Zion Canyon is one of the most popular national parks in the country. With soaring rock formations and awe-inspiring views, this park is particularly radiant at sunrise and sunset. Zion offers a diverse…
entry.content:
Located in Southern Utah, about 3 hours from Las Vegas, the majestic Zion Canyon is one of the most popular national parks in the country. With soaring rock formations and awe-inspiring views, this park is particularly radiant at sunrise and sunset. Zion offers a diverse range of adventure options, from wading through rushing water in the Narrows to taking in the full expanse of the canyon from the top of the death-defying Angel's Landing summit. It also has a facinating history, which only serves to highlight the importance of understanding this park even further.

Check out this grainy but informational video!

entry.title: Welcome to America's National Parks
entry.summary: “There is nothing so American as our national parks…. The fundamental idea behind the parks…is that the country belongs to the people, that it is in process of making for the enrichment of the lives of all of us.” - President Franklin D. Roosevelt…
entry.content:
“There is nothing so American as our national parks…. The fundamental idea behind the parks…is that the country belongs to the people, that it is in process of making for the enrichment of the lives of all of us.” - President Franklin D. Roosevelt

In 1872, Congress created the first national park: Yellowstone National Park. 44 years later, on on August 25, 1916, President Woodrow Wilson established the National Park Service. These two events launched one of the most ambitious and beneficial projects in our nation's history. The National Park System represents some of the best parts of our country, preserving our natural beauty for everyone to enjoy. 

However, this system is not perfect. The national parks are often held on stolen land, taken from indigenous peoples who were never fairly compensated, in a situation where no compensation could ever validate the theft of a home. National parks are also disproportionately enjoyed by white Americans, and undervisited among communities of color. Lost in the beauty of these parks and the overall positivity of this system are these issues and many others.

This website aims to tell two stories: the history of the National Parks system and the story of the opposite perspective, for which the benefit of the parks is not felt in nearly the same way. As the author, I have chosen to focus on a select few parks on the west coast that I have visited (Zion, Yosemite, and Joshua Tree), and each page will attempt to tell both stories, along with images that I have captured there. To find the information that inspired this project, as well as resources for further research, visit the Resources page.
